body: Obvious question perhaps , have you tried running with -noprofile ?
Running with -noprofile results in the same error.

What happens if you run:

```powershell
Get-Module PSReadline -ListAvailable
```

and if you try to load the module manually:

```powershell
Import-Module PSReadline
```

OK, I ran the commands in an admin powershell:

 Get-Module PSReadline -ListAvailable
```
ModuleType Version    PreRelease Name                                PSEdition ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ---------- ----                                --------- ----------------
Script     2.1.0                 PSReadLine                          Desk      {Get-PSReadLineKeyHandler, Set-PSReadLiâ€¦
```
Import-Module PSReadline
```
Import-Module: Errors occurred while loading the format data file:
C:\apps\powershell\7\Modules\PSReadline\PSReadLine.format.ps1xml, , C:\apps\powershell\7\Modules\PSReadline\PSReadLine.format.ps1xml: The file was skipped because of the following validation exception: File C:\apps\powershell\7\Modules\PSReadline\PSReadLine.format.ps1xml cannot be loaded because its operation is blocked by software restriction policies, such as those created by using Group Policy..
```
I've looked at my group policy and I have no idea which setting would be causing this error.

Get-ExecutionPolicy -List
```
         Get-ExecutionPolicy -List

        Scope ExecutionPolicy
        ----- ---------------
MachinePolicy       Undefined
   UserPolicy       Undefined
      Process       Undefined
  CurrentUser    Unrestricted
 LocalMachine    Unrestricted
```
Check the file in windows explorer,  look for the downloaded file block and check the digital signatures page, details says the sig is OK and the signer matches the one on the PSM1 file.

You may also try running

```powershell
Unblock-File C:\apps\powershell\7\Modules\PSReadline\PSReadLine.format.ps1xml
```

> You may also try running
> 
> ```powershell
> Unblock-File C:\apps\powershell\7\Modules\PSReadline\PSReadLine.format.ps1xml
> ```

I tried this but still get the error.

> Check the file in windows explorer, look for the downloaded file block and check the digital signatures page, details says the sig is OK and the signer matches the one on the PSM1 file.

Hmmm... it's telling me a certificate was revoked by the issuer. Any further instructions?

Lets try updating to the latest version. Then reloading the console.

```powershell
Install-Module -Name PSReadline -AllowPrerelease -Force
```

Install-Module -Name PSReadline -AllowPrerelease -Force
`Install-Module: The 'Install-Module' command was found in the module 'PowerShellGet', but the module could not be loaded. For more information, run 'Import-Module PowerShellGet'.`

Import-Module PowerShellGet
`Import-Module: Errors occurred while loading the format data file:
C:\apps\powershell\7\Modules\PowerShellGet\PSGet.Format.ps1xml, , C:\apps\powershell\7\Modules\PowerShellGet\PSGet.Format.ps1xml: The file was skipped because of the following validation exception: File C:\apps\powershell\7\Modules\PowerShellGet\PSGet.Format.ps1xml cannot be loaded because its operation is blocked by software restriction policies, such as those created by using Group Policy..`
For now I'm just using clear in a profile to get rid of this annoying error message. Definitely not ideal!

What are all the different locations for settings files that I can check? I've tried uninstalling and reinstalling but no luck. Is there any surefire way of resetting powershell without refreshing windows?
Trying a windows refresh, keeping files, but chose the option to download from the cloud. So we'll see if this is enough to get rid of the error.

Sounds like Group Policy is the culprit here.,

To find the location of the module:

```console
PS > Get-Module PsReadLine  -List | Format-List -Properety ModuleBase

ModuleBase : C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\PSReadline\2.0.0
```

Refreshing (resetting) the PC did not get rid of the error. Not going to do a clean install right now though.

This command returns nothing:
`Get-Module PSReadLine | Format-List -Property ModuleBase`

Odd - You would seem to have removed PSReadline somehow.

You can also try:

```powershell
Get-Module PsReadLine  -List | Format-List -Property ModuleBase # find any versions on the host
```
If that shows nothing then somehow you have managed to remove the module from PowerShell's ability to find it. I have no idea  how you could have done that. The simplest resolution would be to just reinstall the module using `Install-Module` and specify **PSReadLine*. Then restart PowerShell.

Get-Module PsReadLine  -List | Format-List -Property ModuleBase
```
ModuleBase : C:\apps\powershell\7\Modules\PSReadLine
ModuleBase : C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\PSReadline\2.0.0
```

I was able to get admin to work without the error message following these steps:

Windows Administrative Tools > Local Security Policy > Enforcement > All users except administrators

Then I used `Import-Module PSReadline` in an admin console and from then on my admin consoles have not had the error.

Anyone have any idea how to make my non-admin consoles get rid of the error?

Import-Module PSReadline
`Import-Module: Errors occurred while loading the format data file:
C:\Documents\PowerShell\Modules\PSReadline\PSReadLine.format.ps1xml, , C:\Documents\PowerShell\Modules\PSReadline\PSReadLine.format.ps1xml: The file was skipped because of the following validation exception: File C:\Documents\PowerShell\Modules\PSReadline\PSReadLine.format.ps1xml cannot be loaded because its operation is blocked by software restriction policies, such as those created by using Group Policy..`
Is there a way to install things as an admin but for my user account?

I tried both -Scope Global and -Scope Local as admin which ran without error but did not fix my unelevated console.
` Import-Module PSReadline -Scope Local`
` Import-Module PSReadline -Scope Global`

Oh wow. I found it!
`Install-Module -Name PSReadline -AllowPrerelease -Force`
This didn't work before because I hadn't yet been able to run it even as admin properly. Now that admin is working again I ran this command again (as admin) and it actually fixed my unelevated console. No more error!

I had to use:

```
Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned
Import-Module PSReadline
```

hi all ,

I had meet same error as @garfieldbanks showd above , and try every suggestions list above .

The error still exists.  I could provice some clue which caused  to trigger this error .

I installed powershell extension into  Visual Studio Code  . The  vs code powershell console show me below command today :

> File
> D:\apps\powershell\7\Modules\PSReadline\PSReadLine.format.ps1xml
> is published by CN=Microsoft Corporation, O=Microsoft
> Corporation, L=Redmond, S=Washington, C=US and is not trusted on
> your system. Only run scripts from trusted publishers.
> [V] Never run  [D] Do not run  [R] Run once  [A] Always run
> [?] Help(default is "D"):  V

I comfirmed the question by input  V  , which means   [V] Never run .

After this moment , each time when I open Windows Terminal , there are always show the  message " Cannot load PSReadline module.  Console is running without PSReadline. " , even if set the environment policy to **Unrestricted**  .

At current situation , the only way I can load the PSReadline into console is by run command each time when I open console  :  

> Import-Module 'C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\PSReadline\2.0.0\PSReadline.psd1'

when the current cosole closed , PSReadline module gone too .

> hi all ,
> 
> I had meet same error as @garfieldbanks showd above , and try every suggestions list above .
> 
> The error still exists. I could provice some clue which caused to trigger this error .
> 
> I installed powershell extension into Visual Studio Code . The vs code powershell console show me below command today : 

```  
File <<path>> PSReadLine.format.ps1xml  
is published by  CN=Microsoft Corporation, O=Microsoft Corporation, L=Redmond, S=Washington, C=US  
and is not trusted on  your system. Only run scripts from trusted publishers.
[V] Never run  [D] Do not run  [R] Run once  [A] Always run  [?] Help(default is "D"):  V
```
> I comfirmed the question by input V , which means [V] Never run .
> 
> After this moment , each time when I open Windows Terminal , there are always show the message " Cannot load PSReadline module. Console is running without PSReadline. " , even if set the environment policy to **Unrestricted** .

I was testing something yesterday and I find if I set Policy to **AllSigned** I get the  `PSReadLine.format.ps1xml  is published by Microsoft but isn't trusted` message. 

`Get-AuthenticodeSignature` shows the thumbprint for this file is the same as .psm1 and .psd1 files 

```
EnhancedKeyUsageList : {Microsoft Publisher (1.3.6.1.4.1.311.76.8.1), Code Signing (1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.3)}
NotAfter             : 03/03/2021 18:39:47
NotBefore            : 04/03/2020 18:39:47
SerialNumber         : 3300000187721772155940C709000000000187
Thumbprint           : 2485A7AFA98E178CB8F30C9838346B514AEA4769
Issuer               : CN=Microsoft Code Signing PCA 2011, O=Microsoft Corporation, L=Redmond, S=Washington, C=US
Subject              : CN=Microsoft Corporation, O=Microsoft Corporation, L=Redmond, S=Washington, C=US
```

Note that although this cert has NOW expired it has a certified time stamp of â€Ž02 â€ŽNovember â€Ž2020 22:52:45 when it was valid. 

**PowerShell files are signed with a newer cert,*

``` 
EnhancedKeyUsageList : {Microsoft Publisher (1.3.6.1.4.1.311.76.8.1), Code Signing (1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.3)}
NotAfter             : 01/09/2022 19:32:59
NotBefore            : 02/09/2021 19:32:59
SerialNumber         : 33000002528B33AAF895F339DB000000000252
Thumbprint           : 8740DF4ACB749640AD318E4BE842F72EC651AD80
Issuer               : CN=Microsoft Code Signing PCA 2011, O=Microsoft Corporation, L=Redmond, S=Washington, C=US
Subject              : CN=Microsoft Corporation, O=Microsoft Corporation, L=Redmond, S=Washington, C=US
```

I suspect answering NEVER to `[V] Never run  [D] Do not run  [R] Run once  [A] Always run  [?] `  puts that cert on a dis-trusted list and nothing signed with that will run in future.

>

> when the current cosole closed , PSReadline module gone too .

Hello everyone. This is my first post here so it also serves as a little introduction. I am a c0d3r by heart, php dev since 20 years. I love scripting but i like many languages, scripts, markup, etc... Anyhow - i read about you all's problem. Just today i ran into the same issue after screwing around with powersHell, 4-6 modules paths, NcopyPaste {^_-}

than i got the error when i powershelled in... This is my solution, without touching gPolicy.
in this case we temporary set the execPolicy for localMachine to remoteSigned,
we execute whatever, then we set the policy back to restricted. like so:

 1 > log into an administrator prompt ( ctrl-shift LeftClick ) ; then
 2 > log into the psPrompt - type: powershell  OR
 2 > login to powershell as admin at step 1 and skip that.
 3 > Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope LocalMachine
 x > Import-Module PSReadline
 x > Install-Module PSReadline
 4 > Set-ExecutionPolicy Restricted -Scope LocalMachine
 5 > exit && shutdown /r /f /t 0

that was it for me. let me know if it worked for you too, or not.

#!Cheers,
~Joe.

Not sure what solution you are looking for.
If it were me, I#'d just remove the old module at: ModuleBase : C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\PSReadline.
Removing that folder and everything below, in effect, removes the older module.  And even better, remove the one at C:\apps\powershell\7\Modules\PSReadLine. THEN use Install-module to re-install the module. 

If you are using VS Code and the POwerShell extension, the version of PSReadLine used is fixed by the extension.
Accidently reopened it. Sorry!
